entry.title: This asteroid might not hit Earth in 2032 after all
entry.summary:
Asteroids fly by Earth on a regular basis, and most of them are of no concern whatsoever. But sometimes a space rock gets flagged as a potential threat because there is a slim chance that it may collide with Earth. A newly discovered near-Earth asteroid called 2024 YR4 is one possibly perilous object: It‚Äôs a 130 to 300-foot long rock that could impact somewhere on Earth on December 22, 2032.
To be clear, there is no need to hurriedly invest in a hardened bunker. This asteroid is certainly worth watching because it could devastate a city with a direct hit‚Äîeven on the small side of its size estimate. At one point, the rock had a 3.1 percent chance of a violent rendezvous with Earth‚Äîthe highest ever recorded. The odds have since fallen to 1.5 percent and will most likely, drop precipitou‚Ä¶

entry.title: Amtrak's Gulf Coast train line is back‚Äîhere‚Äôs what‚Äôs to expect
entry.summary:
En route to Biloxi from New Orleans, the train passes Gulfport Beach in Mississippi. Amtrak‚Äôs southern route prepares to reopen, following a 20-year hiatus after Hurricane Katrina.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Linking the Mardi Gras capital of New Orleans in Louisiana and the waterfront city of Mobile in Alabama, Amtrak‚Äôs Gulf Coast train is set to become one of the USA‚Äôs great rail routes once more when it relaunches in spring 2025. Following the southern US shoreline for most of its three-hour journey, it passes through Louisiana‚Äôs Cajun country ‚Äî known for its miles of bayous, traditional festivals and hearty gumbos (spicy Cajun chicken soup) ‚Äî and coastal Mississippi. The latter is a lesser-visited area with white-sand beaches, fresh c‚Ä¶

Ukraine war: Amid shifting alliances, General Assembly passes resolution condemning Russia‚Äôs aggression
entry.summary: Three years to the day since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, the UN General Assembly adopted two competing resolutions on resolving the conflict on Monday, one initiated by the United States and the other by Ukraine ‚Äì a sign of strategic differences within the transatlantic alliance over the way forward for peace.

entry.title: World News in Brief: Famine in Sudan, Gaza polio campaign continues, West Bank update, Kenyan officer killed in Haiti
entry.summary: Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres expressed deep concern on Monday following the announcement by Sudan‚Äôs Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia and affiliated groups, of a political charter proposing the establishment of a rival governing authority in RSF-controlled areas to the transitional Government.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Eastern DR Congo: Crisis deepens amid a surge in crime and insecurity
entry.summary: The humanitarian crisis in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) is worsening as M23 rebel attacks continue to drive tens of thousands from their homes and claim hundreds of lives, UN humanitarians warned on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Nuclear weapons are ‚Äòone-way road to annihilation‚Äô warns Guterres
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres on Monday warned that the risk of nuclear conflict is rising ‚Äì as global security arrangements unravel and military spending soars ‚Äì urging governments to push for total disarmament.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN report urges Colombia to protect civilians amid ongoing violence
entry.summary: The UN human rights office (OHCHR)¬†has issued a stark warning about ongoing violence in Colombia perpetrated by armed groups and criminal organisations, which threatens the country‚Äôs nearly ten year old peace accord.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Breast cancer cases projected to rise by nearly 40 per cent by 2050, WHO warns
entry.summary: Breast cancer cases are expected to increase by 38 percent globally by 2050, with annual deaths from the disease projected to rise by 68 percent, according to a new report from the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), a specialised branch of the World Health Organization (WHO).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UKRAINE LIVE: Diplomatic debate steps up a gear as world marks three years since full-scale Russian invasion
entry.summary: February 24 marks three years since Russia launched a full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Thousands of civilians have been killed and injured, the economy shattered and energy infrastructure destroyed. As the General Assembly and Security Council meet and debate how peace and security can be restored in eastern Europe, we will be providing rolling coverage. Competing resolutions from Ukraine and the US point to a day of consequential diplomacy. UN News app users can follow live here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World‚Äôs ‚Äòwarmongers‚Äô must end disdain for global order, UN chief insists
entry.summary: With no end to numerous protracted conflicts - not least in Ukraine, three years to the day since the full-scale Russian invasion - UN chief Ant√≥nio Guterres on Monday scorned the world‚Äôs ‚Äúwarmongers‚Äù for trampling on people‚Äôs most fundamental rights.

entry.title: Go on a luxury rail journey through Peruvian mountains
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Holding aloft pairs of dry coca leaves, the dancers pause, drums beating faster, before they burst into song. Over shouts of ‚ÄúHeh! Heh! Heh!‚Äù, they play melodies on a quena (an Andean flute) while passengers gather around, squinting through the smoke from offerings burning on the platform at Poroy Station. Coloured with vegetable dyes, the welcome troupe‚Äôs skirts flare as they hop from one foot to the other, setting the tone for the next four hours: a journey filled with music, colour and Indigenous Quechua culture.
I‚Äôm here to ride the luxury Hiram Bingham, run by Belmond Trains, from the district of Cusco in southeastern Peru to the town of Aguas Calientes in the foothills of the ancient Inca citadel of Machu Pic‚Ä¶

entry.title: In Catalonia, try this self-sufficient fine-dining restaurant
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In the hills to the west of Barcelona, Casa Nova is a temple to the art of slow, soulful cooking. It‚Äôs the kind of place that, using only what is naturally abundant, relies on age-old methods and the particularities of a region‚Äôs terrain, climate and cultures.
In fact, the restaurant, a farmhouse in the fertile Pened√®s countryside famed for its white wines, claims to be 98% self-sufficient, with the remainder sourced from local producers. There are just seven staff who grow, cook, deliver and then explain all the food ‚Äî no waiters ‚Äî and a dining room with only six tables, Casa Nova offers an experience akin to visiting a friend‚Äôs farm ‚Äî if that friend happened to be one of the world's most innovative chefs.

entry.title: Using WhatsApp to Crowdsource Data on Ride Hailing Companies‚Äô Labor Lockouts
entry.summary: Bloomberg investigative data journalist Leon Yin used WhatsApp to crowdsource data from Uber and Lyft drivers in New York City about company lockouts during a local, minimum wage dispute.

entry.title: GIJN Webinar: The Future of Funding Investigative Journalism: Strategies & Challenges
entry.summary: In this GIJN webinar, attendees will learn how to diversify revenue streams, approach funders while safeguarding editorial independence, and adapt to the evolving funding landscape. The panel brings together three top experts with deep experience in media fundraising, business strategy, and philanthropic support for journalism, ready to share their knowledge and real-world strategies.

entry.title: Greenland: life at the edge of the world
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The Inuit of Greenland have 80 different words for ice. Niels Davidsen is currently most familiar with sikuuvoq (sea covered by a layer of ice) because the sikuuvoq has stolen his boat. It is currently sikkuppaa (frozen into sea ice) in the harbour of Ilulissat, on the west coast of Greenland, and there it will stay for a couple more months. Come June, the thaw will rescue the vessel and its many neighbours, or else the town will decide its winter visitor has outstayed its welcome and employ an ice-breaker or dynamite to swiftly blast an ammavoq (passage in sea ice for a boat to pass through) and be done with it.
For now, though, Niels visits his little white boat in Illulissat harbour every so often to chip off th‚Ä¶

Ukraine: Guterres says ‚ÄòEnough is Enough‚Äô as war reaches the three-year mark
entry.summary: Monday marks three years since Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, in clear violation of the UN Charter and international law, and the UN Secretary-General has renewed his call for de-escalation and an end to the conflict.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraine three years on: Pain, loss, solidarity and hope for a better future
entry.summary: 24 February 2025 marks the third year of the full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, and the civilian population continues to face near daily-attacks. The UN staff living alongside them, enduring the same difficult conditions, have been a lifeline throughout the war.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.summary: With 26 Michelin stars found across its historic streets, Copenhagen is undeniably a culinary powerhouse. The city is home to some of the world‚Äôs most innovative restaurants ‚Äî including Alchemist, a theatrical dining experience headed by Rasmus Munk, the reigning World‚Äôs Best Chef ‚Äî yet, there‚Äôs no need to break the bank on a visit here. There are plenty of affordable restaurants showcasing traditional Danish cuisine, as well as first-rate bakeries, where you‚Äôll find delights like the ‚ÄòViennese‚Äô (a pastry named after the city in which its Danish creator found inspiration). On a winter visit, join the locals on a quest to find the city‚Äôs best fastelavnsboller ‚Äî seasonal cakes that liven up bakery windows from January onwards. entry.title: 8 of the most scenic train journeys in the UK
entry.summary:
The North Yorkshire Moors Railway was first launched in the 1830s. UK rail is once again in the spotlight as the country marks the 200<sup>th</sup> anniversary of the world‚Äôs first public railway this year. Pay tribute to those early pioneers by riding the UK‚Äôs most scenic rails.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Mainland Europe has been basking in a not-so-quiet rail revolution for the past few years, but now the spotlight is firmly on the UK. 2025 marks 200 years since the opening of the Stockton and Darlington Railway ‚Äî the world‚Äôs first public railway ‚Äî and the much-anticipated Britannic Explorer, A Belmond Train arrives in July. As train travel across the UK takes off once more, here are eight train journeys with views you won‚Äôt want to mi‚Ä¶

entry.title: Rose gardens, souks and outdoor adventures in Oman‚Äôs green peaks
entry.summary: High in¬†the¬†rocky mountains of Oman‚Äôs interior,¬†the¬†desert¬†blooms, beckoning travellers to experience a corner of the country that's resplendent in its rural beauty. Jabal Akhdar is around two hours' drive from Muscat and enjoys a mild microclimate thanks to an inland position and high altitude. As a result, it's home to flourishing landscapes, with fruit and rose orchards smothering slopes in fragrant and colourful blossoms. Visitors can easily immerse themselves in its spectacularly rugged landscapes on foot, with the milder weather providing ample opportunities for exploration of its villages and hiking routes. Witness the plunging depths of nearby Wadi Ghul ‚Äî nicknamed ‚Äòthe Grand Canyon of Arabia‚Äô, while ancient settlements carved into Jabal Akhdar's precipices add a surreal beauty to ‚Ä¶

entry.title: New round of polio vaccinations begins in Gaza
entry.summary: The latest large-scale polio vaccination drive in Gaza targeting some 600,000 children under age 10 got underway on Saturday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN in Ukraine prepares for the worst, hopes for the best
entry.summary: As the full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine reaches its third year, a flurry of diplomatic activity has led to a growing expectation of a ceasefire, although the situation remains extremely fluid. Despite the uncertainty, the UN is planning how to best support the country when the fighting finally stops.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Explainer: 5 common myths about child marriage
entry.summary: Every day, almost¬†one in five young women are married off while still children, according to the UN reproductive and sexual health agency, UNFPA, which is urging countries to say ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt‚Äù to child marriage, an illegal practice that is almost universally condemned and yet remains widespread globally.

entry.title: Try this destination for cherry blossoms instead of Japan
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The end of South Korea‚Äôs long, frigid winter is announced by puffs of pink and white. Cherry blossom season is a big deal here, celebrated with local festivals and flower-themed drinks ‚Äî and it‚Äôs as beautiful as it is fleeting. Southern Jeju island sees its first blossom in mid-March, while up in the mountains of the northern mainland, buds can linger on until the end of April. The blooms usually peak a week or so after first appearing, and soon after lie in pale mounds on the ground.
It‚Äôs difficult to avoid comparisons with neighbouring Japan, over the sea. There, cherry blossom-viewing ‚Äî an experience known locally as hanami ‚Äî is more well-established. But South Korea is the more affordable of the two countries, ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Antoni Porowski wants you to learn your ancestors‚Äô recipes
entry.summary: Chef Fabio Delledone shows Antoni Porowski and actor Justin Theroux how to make tortelli at Ristorante Belrespiro in Agazzano, Italy. As the host of No Taste Like Home, Porowski travels with celebrities to their ancestral homeland to explore their genealogy and the origins of their family‚Äôs culinary traditions. The Queer Eye star discusses his obsession with food, and helping others find their family history through food in the new travel series No Taste Like Home. Antoni Porowski believes in the importance of storytelling through culinary traditions. The child of Polish parents who immigrated to Montr√©al, he ‚Äúfelt Polish enough‚Äù until the family moved to West Virginia and he began high school. Wanting to hang out with the cool kids, he started to notice how he‚Ä¶

entry.title: It‚Äôs possible to reverse diabetes‚Äîand even faster than you think
entry.summary:
Diabetes is a debilitating, life-threatening chronic illness that puts people at greater risk of blindness, kidney failure, and heart disease. But we‚Äôre also increasingly learning that it‚Äôs not a condition a person needs to live with forever.¬†
One in 10 people in the United States and more than 830 million¬†people worldwide have the disease‚Äî91 percent of them with type 2 diabetes; which, unlike type 1 diabetes, tends to develop in adulthood. About a¬†third of Americans also have prediabetes‚Äîthough more than 80 percent of them¬†don't know they have it.
"Type 2 diabetes is like having termites in your home in that it doesn't show¬†many symptoms at first, but can cause significant internal damage over time," says Osama Hamdy, senior staff physician at the Joslin Diabetes Center¬†in Massa‚Ä¶

By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
If you‚Äôre planning to travel outside the United States, you need a reliable travel adapter and power converter. Differences in international power grids means there are no universal standards for voltage, frequency, or plug types around the world. Depending on where you go and which devices you‚Äôre charging, you may need an adapter, a converter, or both.¬†
A travel adapter simply lets you plug into different outlets. A converter adjusts the voltage s‚Ä¶

entry.title: Winter brings more indoor air pollution
entry.summary:
Most of us associate air pollution with the outdoors‚Äîfrom car or bus exhaust in a city to industrial waste or wildfire smoke. But you may not realize the air inside your home can be even more contaminated, especially in winter. Since home is where we spend some 70 percent of our time‚Äîmore if you‚Äôre one of the 35 percent of workers who do some or all business from there‚Äîthese toxins can have an outsized impact on your health.
Outdoor pollutants are regulated by the Clean Air Act, but no comparable federal law governs what lurks inside your dwelling. Yet exposure to common winter indoor toxins can cause myriad health conditions, including respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, chronic inflammation, and cancer. Some research has even linked them to premature death, says Nicholas Nassik‚Ä¶

entry.title: Near perfect skull of apex predator reveals its 'meat cleaving bite'
entry.summary:
A species of the Hyaenodonta family as depicted by Heinrich Harder in Wilhelm Bolsche‚Äôs Tiere der Urwelt (Animals of the Prehistoric World). A new fossil from this extinct predator gives scientists clues to how it lived and hunted. Some were the size of a dog. Others were as large as polar bears. A newly-discovered fossil of the ferocious hyaenodont is helping scientists understand a little bit more about the mysterious creatures.
Long before wolves or big cats, large hyaenodonts prowled the landscape.
Despite their name, the carnivores were not hyenas. Hyaenodonts were an ancient group of four-legged flesh-eaters that spread from ancient Europe through Africa, Asia, and North America between 56 and about 5 million years ago.
Most were small, comparable to a medium-sized‚Ä¶

entry.title: This is what a surgical clinic looked like in ancient Rome
entry.summary:
A mosaic of Orpheus ringed by animals paves the floor of what archaeologists believe was the consulting room of the early third-century A.D. Surgeon‚Äôs House of Rimini, Italy. Discovered on accident in Rimini, Italy, this surgeon‚Äôs house and the hooks, scalpels, and mortars inside have expanded what we knew about ancient medicine.
Workers were hardly surprised when they stumbled upon ancient ruins in the Italian town of Rimini in 1989. Now a popular tourist destination along the Adriatic coast, Rimini‚Äîor Ariminum in ancient times‚Äîhad been a major Roman town for centuries, and the modern city is strewn with monuments from that period.
What the workers found that spring day, however, would lead archaeologists to something quite unique: a cache of surgical instruments that had lai‚Ä¶

How to plan a tour of Italy's hidden wine region
entry.summary:
Shouldering up to the Alps with undulating vine-ribbed hills and glassy lakes, Lombardy is as easy on the eye as it is on the palate. The wine routes that thread through this northern corner of Italy pass through everything from clifftop villages, buzzing piazzas and alley-woven hill towns to medieval castles and Renaissance palazzi (palaces).
The ancient Greeks ‚Äî who brought viticulture to the region over a millennia ago ‚Äî knew the terroir was special, thanks to the diverse surrounding landscapes that include the Alps, the Po River Valley and some of Italy's most stunning lakes. Still, for all its beauty and fine wines, it can be difficult to know where to start when it comes to exploring Lombardy's wine areas. Here are four of the best routes to drive, hike or bike through the regio‚Ä¶

entry.title: Colombia: Fleeing the thunder of violence in Catatumbo
entry.summary: Around 80,000 people in northeastern Colombia are suffering the devastating consequences of an armed conflict that escalated on 15 January of this year. Caught in the crossfire between armed groups, thousands have been forced to flee with nothing but the clothes on their backs while others remain trapped in their homes.

entry.title: Security Council condemns M23 offensive in eastern DR Congo
entry.summary: The UN Security unanimously adopted a resolution on Friday that strongly condemns the ongoing offensive and advance of M23 rebels in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Nearly 148,000 in Gaza receive cash aid
entry.summary: Aid operations in the Gaza Strip continue to reach people from north to south with critical assistance, including cash, the UN humanitarian affairs office, OCHA, said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo crisis: Occupation blocks UN mission from protecting civilians
entry.summary: The continued occupation of North Kivu in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) by the M23 armed group has ‚Äúseverely constrained‚Äù the UN stabilisation force‚Äôs ability to protect civilians and carry out lifesaving operations, the mission chief Bintou Keita told reporters on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Urgent appeal launched as DR Congo crisis fuels mass displacement to Burundi
entry.summary: The UN refugee agency, UNHCR, has launched a $40.4 million appeal to address the deepening humanitarian crisis in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and its impact on neighbouring countries, particularly Burundi, where thousands are arriving daily in desperate conditions.

entry.summary: In the nearly three years since the full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, the country‚Äôs people have endured continuous attacks, ‚Äúpsychological terror‚Ä¶displacement and hardship‚Äù, top UN aid coordinator Matthias Schmale said on Friday.

entry.title: Some of the best dishes to try in Dubai right now
entry.summary:
Reif Japanese Kushiyaki‚Äôs Wagyu katsu sando features Australian tenderloin between slices of milk bread. In the emirate you‚Äôll find dishes adorned with everything from caviar to crisps.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The food scene in Dubai is much like its skyline: ever-changing. Chefs constantly add new flavours to menus that represent the multitude of nationalities that call the emirate home. And while it‚Äôs known for its opulent fine dining and pull-out-all-the-stops brunches, there are places to suit even more modest budgets, from homely holes-in-the-wall to Michelin Bib Gourmand-recommended restaurants.
Chef Reif Othman‚Äôs well-priced, artfully presented dishes have earned this relaxed neighbourhood spot a Michelin Bib Gourmand fo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why 'White Lotus' fans should travel to this island instead
entry.summary: Fans of The White Lotus should consider checking into the luxurious Six Senses Fiji on Malolo Island. If the set-jetting White Lotus Effect continues, travelers may want to visit the lesser-crowded Malolo Island, Fiji, instead of Koh Samui, Thailand. The latest season is set on the beautiful island of Koh Samui, which will undoubtedly lead to an influx of tourists. Fiji's Malolo Island offers a similar idyllic tropical getaway‚Äîwithout the crowds. The luxury resorts and¬†picturesque destinations¬†featured on the popular series The White Lotus have inspired fans and increased tourism to the real stars of the show, but not every locale has been able to adequately handle the influx of new visitors. entry.title: Is gluten really that bad for you?
entry.summary:
Gluten-free eating has skyrocketed in popularity over the past decade, fueled by claims that cutting gluten leads to better health. This trend shows no signs of slowing down, with the global market for gluten-free foods projected to be valued at $14 billion by 2032.
But is ditching gluten a good idea? While some people must cut it out for medical reasons, millions of others have embraced the diet without a clear need. Here‚Äôs what science says about gluten, why it‚Äôs become so controversial, and what happens to your body when you stop eating it.
‚ÄúGluten is a protein found in wheat, rye, and barley,‚Äù says Melinda Dennis, a registered dietitian and nutrition coordinator at the Celiac Center at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston (BIDMC). ‚ÄúIt acts as a binding agent in fo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Beef tallow as skin care? Experts explain what‚Äôs truth‚Äîand myth
entry.summary:
You may have seen beef tallow, a product rendered from cow fat, touted as an answer to dry skin woes. It may seem like something you eat would be fine to put on your skin‚Äîbut experts say there are better, clinically proven options.
It‚Äôs not just for searing up steaks or deep frying french fries anymore. Beef tallow, the humble cow fat byproduct, has been making its way into beauty routines.
Citing vitamins and other biochemical benefits, some influencers and wellness gurus are touting beef tallow as the latest hack for soft, dewy skin. With a growing interest in ‚Äúclean‚Äù and ‚Äúnatural‚Äù skincare alternatives, it‚Äôs perhaps no surprise that animal products‚Äîlike beef tallow and snail mucin‚Äîare having a moment in cosmetics.
But does processed cow fat really belong on our cheeks?‚Ä¶

entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It‚Äôs too late to turn back now ‚Äî the priest is waiting for us. I shut my eyes and grip the seat belt as my guide and I rattle down the steep, rocky mountainside. We‚Äôre heading towards the isolated Mount Kailash Rejuvenation Centre, a winding 30-minute drive from St Lucia‚Äôs capital, Castries, and, after what feels like a mile-long bumpy descent, I can finally open my eyes again. The Honourable Priest Kailash, the founder of the centre, greets us with freshly cut coconuts and we sip the sweet, cool water from inside. ‚ÄúBlessed,‚Äù he says, motioning us towards one of the herb gardens. ‚ÄúWelcome to Mount Kailash.‚Äù
Before settling on the secluded peak where his farm stands, Priest Kailash studied medicine and built a reput‚Ä¶

entry.title: How chocolate went from rough to refined in one Sicilian town
entry.summary:
Simone Sabaini is on a pursuit to refine the grainy Modica chocolate. After moving to Sicily for a simpler life, former investment banker Simone Sabaini helped to reinvent Modica‚Äôs sweet scene.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
‚ÄúI never liked Modica chocolate. I thought it was just a tourist product with many defects,‚Äù says Simone Sabaini. ‚ÄúAs soon as I started living here, I understood why I didn‚Äôt like it and set about trying to make it better.‚Äù
Modica‚Äôs crumbly, grainy chocolate isn‚Äôt to everyone‚Äôs taste. When the Spanish brought cocoa beans to Sicily during their 500-year occupation, they combined them with sugar to make a rustic bar using a technique learned from the Aztecs. entry.title: How a penguin ‚Äòdivorce‚Äô can impact a whole colony
entry.summary: Little blue penguins (Eudyptula minor) like this pair silhouetted against Melbourne city lights inhabit coastal areas in Australia and New Zealand. Like other species, these penguins sometimes split from partners, and researchers have found that the number of divorces impact the health of a colony. Little blue penguin break-up rates are a new tool that could predict their colony‚Äôs future in the face of climate change and habitat loss. You might have heard that penguins mate for life, but for little penguins, the grass is often greener. These tiny birds, found in Australia and New Zealand, divorce their mate if they're not happy with how many chicks they're producing. ‚ÄúDivorce and nookie in the local hotel is a really important part of [a penguin‚Äôs] life,‚Äù says Rory Wils‚Ä¶

entry.title: These national park trails were created by America‚Äôs first Black soldiers
entry.summary:
The Black soldier above served in the American Army's Ninth Cavalry, also known as Buffalo Soldiers. They were assigned several duties, which included patrolling and protecting the first national parks in the U.S. before the National Park Service was established in 1916. Follow in the footsteps of the Buffalo Soldiers, who guarded parks and created trails in Yosemite, Sequoia, and Hawai‚Äôi Volcanoes National Parks.
You may not have heard about the Buffalo Soldiers, but they were professional Black enlistees serving in the first segregated regiments of the regular peacetime U.S. Army formed after the Civil War. But you have no doubt benefited from the legacy they left in America‚Äôs national parks and you may have even traversed the roads and trails they built.¬†¬†¬†¬†

entry.title: This instrument tuner keeps tango music alive
entry.summary:
‚ÄúCan you hear that?‚Äù Dami√°n Guttlein sat at his kitchen table on a recent winter afternoon in Buenos Aires. The 52-year-old held in his hands an old instrument, resembling an accordion, called a bandoneon. As he tested its sound, he tapped on one of the bandoneon‚Äôs many buttons and pulled slightly, giving it air, letting it breathe. ‚ÄúCan you hear it‚Äôs off?‚Äù he said. The note sounded like two notes at once, slightly dissonant.
With a quick flick of the wrists, Guttlein popped off the outer button case to reveal the instrument‚Äôs wooden interior, lined with rows of plated metal reeds. With a file, he began scraping at the one that corresponded to the note he‚Äôd just played, slowly removing a thin layer of steel. Then, he held the file between his teeth as he snapped the button case back o‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to turn a layover into a second vacation
entry.summary:
New York City's East Coast location makes it an ideal stop for travelers heading overseas. Swap the airport for some fresh air, and spend a day or two sightseeing before continuing on your trip. Learn how to extend your stay in some of the best destinations for a long layover‚Äîand how to make the most of your time there.
Layovers are an unavoidable part of travel that rarely spark joy. Why? Because they often afford extensive periods of sitting and waiting, or grant you just 30 minutes to sprint across city-sized airports at Olympic speeds to catch the next flight.
Sometimes, it‚Äôs a debate of whether seven hours is enough time to go through customs, leave the airport to explore, then come back and go through security again. Occasionally, you‚Äôre contending with an awkward 12-hou‚Ä¶

entry.title: Walking is great for your health. Walking backward? Even better.
entry.summary:
Walking is one of the simplest and most accessible ways to stay fit, but taking a few steps in reverse could unlock even greater benefits. This seemingly unconventional movement, known as retro walking, is gaining attention for improving balance, strengthening underused muscles, and even sharpening cognitive function.
The practice isn‚Äôt new‚Äîrecords suggest that backward walking has been part of traditional exercise routines in China for centuries. Athletes and coaches later embraced it to enhance sports performance. Now, researchers are uncovering just how powerful this small change in movement can be.
Unlike forward walking, which primarily engages the ankles, walking backward shifts the workload to the hips and knees. This subtle change in movement activates different muscle ‚Ä¶

entry.title: I took a leap of faith‚Äîand it led me in search of history‚Äôs lost slave ships
entry.summary: National Geographic Explorer Tara Roberts found her purpose as a scuba diver who documents slave ships that wrecked in the Atlantic Ocean with the intent of rediscovering the lost history of the African diaspora. Nat Geo Explorer Tara Roberts quit her job, learned to dive, and now helps discover the underwater wrecks of slave ships around the world with an incredible group of Black conservationists. In this excerpt from her new book Written in the Waters: A Memoir of History, Home, and Belonging, National Geographic Explorer Tara Roberts recounts the start of her journey as a chance introduction to a team of Black scuba experts inspires her to learn to dive, and help reclaim Blac‚Ä¶

entry.title: 8 of the best outdoor experiences in Guatemala
entry.summary:
Guatemala squeezes a continent‚Äôs worth of nature into a compact country. The landscape shifts dramatically between its borders, from active volcanoes to lowland rainforest, and from black-sand beaches pounded by Pacific swells to natural pools as turquoise as they‚Äôre tranquil. For travellers with energy to spare, no two days need look the same.
Earth puts on an incandescent live show in Guatemala, a country with 37 volcanoes, three of which are active. Options for exploring this geotourism hotspot include everything from moderate hikes to lava fields and crater lakes, to challenging multi-day adventures up Central America‚Äôs highest peaks.
The headline act is Volc√°n de Fuego, a 12,362ft cone of heat and fury that hurls lava and ash into the sky sometimes as frequently as every 1‚Ä¶

entry.summary: I published an interactive guide on reading charts, spotting the misleading ones, and visualizing data honestly. Here's the process I used to get there. Tags: behind the scenes, defense

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 161 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from Jan. 27 to Feb. 2, 2025. A total of 5,086 panelists responded out of 5,699 who were sampled, [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Americans Continue to View Several Economic Issues as Top National Problems
entry.summary: At the start of President Donald Trump‚Äôs second term, Americans see a host of economic issues, including inflation, as top problems facing the country. The post Americans Continue to View Several Economic Issues as Top National Problems appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.summary: In recent years, the term "social justice" has become a significant part of public discourse, often invoked in discussions about equality, human rights, and societal reforms. But what exactly does social justice mean, and why is it so important?

entry.summary: Three years of war in Ukraine have reversed decades of progress for women and girls, leaving millions in urgent need of support, according to UN Women.

entry.summary: The dream of a civil, democratic and prosperous Libya remains unfulfilled 14 years after the revolution that led to the overthrow of the Gaddafi regime, the head of UN Political and Peacebuilding Affairs told the Security Council on Wednesday.

entry.title: DR CONGO: Live updates as Security Council meets to avert widening war
entry.summary: Intensifying violence in the eastern region of the Democratic Republic of the Congo continues to displace thousands as the Rwanda-backed M23 armed group threatens to march on the distant capital, Kinshasa, and the UN Security Council holds an emergency meeting to head off regional war. App users can follow our live coverage here.

entry.title: World News in Brief: $53.2 billion needed for Palestinian recovery, UN condemns UNRWA schools raid, Lebanon-Israel tensions continue
entry.summary: The reconstruction of Gaza and the occupied West Bank will require an estimated $53.2 billion over the next ten years, according to the latest Damage and Needs Assessment from the UN and partners.

entry.summary: Strengthening international cooperation and delivering on a UN pact that calls for reforming global governance, among other measures, was the focus of debate in the Security Council on Tuesday.

entry.title: UN environment agency calls for urgent action on ‚Äòtriple planetary crisis‚Äô
entry.summary: The UN Environment Programme (UNEP) called on Tuesday for urgent action to combat climate change, biodiversity loss, and pollution, warning that progress on all fronts remains slow and uneven.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo: Children reportedly killed in summary executions by M23 fighters
entry.summary: The humanitarian emergency in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) has deteriorated sharply with serious human rights violations and abuses, including reported summary executions of children and generalised sexual violence.

entry.title: Multilateralism: What is it, and why does it matter?
entry.summary: Multilateralism is a term frequently used at the United Nations, but it‚Äôs not a concept that is only relevant to the corridors and conference rooms where international diplomacy takes place.

entry.summary: The UN human rights office (OHCHR) on Tuesday sounded the alarm over escalating rights abuses in Sudan, warning that impunity is driving violations as fighting spreads and more armed groups become involved.

entry.title: Open letter from former Census Bureau director
entry.summary: Robert Santos, who resigned last month, wrote a heartfelt open letter to Census‚Ä¶ Tags: Census Bureau, government, Robert Santos

entry.title: Asia-Pacific falling behind on sustainable development and climate targets
entry.summary: The Asia-Pacific region is significantly off track in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), with most targets either stalled or off pace ‚Äì despite ongoing efforts, according to a new UN report.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria: Mine casualties persist as UN partners scale up clearance operations
entry.summary: Explosive ordnance continues to claim lives across Syria, with more than 430 deaths and injuries reported since December, nearly a third of them children, according to St√©phane Dujarric, the Spokesperson for the Secretary-General.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Humanitarians underscore need for urgent and sustained support in Gaza
entry.summary: As the UN and partners continue to deliver life-saving assistance across the Gaza Strip, the scale of needs remains overwhelming, requiring urgent and sustained support, UN aid coordination office OCHA said on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine paramount, Security Council hears
entry.summary: A senior UN political affairs official on Monday reaffirmed that any peace deal in Ukraine must respect the country‚Äôs sovereignty, independence, and territorial integrity, in accordance with the UN Charter and international law.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN launches $6 billion Sudan appeal, as famine takes hold
entry.summary: More than one in two people in war-torn Sudan have too little to eat, famine ‚Äúis taking hold‚Äù and sexual violence is rife, the UN‚Äôs top aid official said on Monday, as the global body launched an¬†appeal for $6 billion to avert a humanitarian catastrophe in the devastated country and beyond.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo crisis: WFP condemns looting in Bukavu after M23 rebels take key city
entry.summary: The UN World Food Programme (WFP) has condemned the looting of thousands of tonnes of relief supplies in the city of Bukavu in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), after Rwanda-backed M23 rebels swept in at the weekend, reportedly meeting little resistance.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: The USAID Crisis and Funding the Future of Independent Media

entry.title: Africa 'brimming with hope and possibility': Guterres
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General, Ant√≥nio Guterres, emphasized the potential of Africa and its young population and called for global reforms to right the injustices of the past, in remarks delivered to the high-level African Union (AU) summit on Saturday.

entry.title: Sudan, ‚Äòthe most devastating humanitarian and displacement crisis in the world‚Äô
entry.summary: Sudan‚Äôs ruinous civil war is approaching its third year, leaving a legacy of malnutrition, massive population displacement and chronic insecurity. As the UN system prepares to launch a call for record funding of $4.2 billion to support aid operations in the country, here are some of the main things to know about what has been¬†described as the largest and most devasting displacement, humanitarian and protection crisis in the world today.

entry.title: 4. How COVID-19 impacted Americans‚Äô relationship with technology
entry.summary: Colleen McClain, Olivia Sidoti and Monica Anderson contributed to this chapter. For many Americans, life in the early days of COVID-19 was lived on screens. Schools pivoted to virtual learning and businesses shuttered or moved online as in-person contact risked spreading the virus. Not everyone could ‚Äì or wanted to ‚Äì avoid in-person interaction. And [‚Ä¶] The post 4. How COVID-19 impacted Americans‚Äô relationship with technology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. How the COVID-19 pandemic affected U.S. religious life
entry.summary: Michael Rotolo contributed to this chapter. The COVID-19 pandemic had an enormous impact on how religious communities gather for worship. In a Pew Research Center survey in July 2020, a few months after the coronavirus struck the United States, just 6% of Americans who regularly attend religious services said their house of worship was open [‚Ä¶] The post 3. How the COVID-19 pandemic affected U.S. religious life appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. How COVID-19 changed U.S. workplaces
entry.summary: Kim Parker contributed to this chapter. The COVID-19 pandemic sent shockwaves through the U.S. labor market. Businesses shuttered, millions of Americans lost their jobs, and for many others their home became their workplace. We tracked these changes starting from the early months of the coronavirus outbreak. Our trends outline the journey workers have been through. [‚Ä¶] The post 2. How COVID-19 changed U.S. workplaces appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Americans‚Äô views on COVID-19 risk and the country‚Äôs response to health emergencies
entry.summary: Eileen Yam and Giancarlo Pasquini contributed to this chapter. Five years after the pandemic began, Americans largely see COVID-19 through the rear-view mirror. Overall, they don‚Äôt feel the virus is nearly as much of a danger as they did in 2020. Still, deep political divides persist about the disease. entry.title: 5 Years Later: America Looks Back at the Impact of COVID-19
entry.summary: Nearly three-quarters of U.S. adults (72%) say the COVID-19 pandemic did more to drive the country apart than to bring it together. The post 5 Years Later: America Looks Back at the Impact of COVID-19 appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: The cheekiest potter
entry.summary: A ceramicist puts a playful twist on Italian Renaissance pottery with dirty jokes, emojis and colourful commentary on menopause - by Aeon Video Watch at Aeon

entry.title: Poverty is not permanent
entry.summary: By understanding the pernicious myths surrounding poverty, we can make progress towards a lofty goal: dignity for all - by Anirudh Krishna & Dirk Philipsen Read at Aeon
